repnme.cdata!: Georgia - Second Social Investment Fund Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Social Investment
            Fund Project for Georgia were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower
            performance was satisfactory. There were a number of
            important lessons learned on project sustainability under
            the Georgia Social Investment Fund (GSIF) II Project
            covering the: (i) the need to focus on local-self governing
            structures and to develop an effective framework (structure,
            systems and procedures) to facilitate interaction between
            community members and local self-government authorities.
            This was essential in helping move communities and local
            self-governments from a dependency culture focused on
            short-term interventions to one that recognizes that
            communities can have the ability to improve their living
            conditions and prospects for sustainable development through
            the active involvement of community members; (ii) the
            importance of focusing on implementation arrangements
            incorporating institutional mechanisms aimed at building
            organizational capacities of communities; (iii) the need to
            ensure good quality of works though improved procedures and
            an enhanced monitoring and supervision framework; (iv) the
            need to devote greater attention to operations and
            maintenance of micro-projects by ensuring adequate
            demand-orientation and community participation in the choice
            of subprojects and through local-capacity building; and (v)
            the importance of institutionalizing the administration of
            micro-projects in the government structure to create
            effective linkages between the central government and local
            communities, ensure effective service delivery through
            qualified staff in the government structure, and thereby
            sustain project activities beyond project implementation.

5085707.trustfund:
TF026883-PHRD-GEORGIA: SOCIAL INVESTMENT
            FUND II PROJECT
5085707.majtheme: Public sector governance,Rural development,Social dev/gender/inclusion,Social protection and risk management

repnme.cdata!: Georgia - Second Social Investment Fund Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Social Investment Fund
            Project for Georgia's development objectives are: a)
            participating local government levels use enhanced
            management skills and a participatory process in
            establishing local development plans and setting investment
            priorities; b) participating poor communities apply for,
            manage, and use micro-projects in a sustainable manner; and
            c) participating poor communities benefit from improved
            social and economic infrastructure and related services. To
            that end, the project will place an explicit emphasis on
            strengthening the interaction between local government level
            and citizens in improving the quality of life in
            communities. It will undertake capacity building and asset
            management at the local government level. At the community
            level, it will develop community mobilization and advocacy
            skills to strengthen self-reliance and self-help mechanisms.
            There are three components: 1) capacity building at local
            community and self-government levels, through training in
            management and administrative skills; 2) identification,
            development and implementation of community based
            micro-projects; and 3) project management costs. While the
            project will be nationwide in scope, the primary target
            group will be the poor communities in peri-urban areas,
            rural towns and villages.

2135527.trustfund:
TF026883-PHRD-GEORGIA: SOCIAL INVESTMENT

repnme.cdata!:
Georgia - Second Social Investment Fund
            Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
These are the guidelines on
            environmental procedures to be followed under the framework
            of the Second Social Investment Fund Project, which identify
            environmental impacts resulting from the project
            implementation, review the country's environmental laws
            and regulations, and assess mitigation measures. The
            infrastructure works concerning primary health, and
            education facility micro-projects, will potentially induce
            contamination from waste materials, hamper drainage systems
            and water quality, due to polluted effluents and hazardous
            wastes, as well as impact air quality, disturb natural
            habitats, and affect the social environment. Measures to
            mitigate these effects call for the protection of soil
            surfaces, through a daily clean-up and control in
            construction sites, which includes the provision of adequate
            waste disposal services; drainage systems should be
            inspected regularly, taking into consideration a special
            disposal of oil, and hazardous materials, and, include as
            well adequate sanitation, and waste disposal systems;
            construction will be restricted to daytime working schedules
            to reduce noise disturbances; and, degradation of natural
            vegetation should be avoided as possible by considering
            alternative sites, and re-vegetation practices following
            construction. Works regarding water supply, small scale
            irrigation, wastewater and sewage, and, waste management
            micro-projects should consider mitigation as follows: soil
            degradation should be protected during construction through
            vegetative propagation and physical stabilization of soils;
            preventive water contamination should consider a minimal
            distance from human settlements and agricultural areas, and
            appropriate drainage; waterborne diseases should be taken
            into account, particularly through appropriate design,
            testing, and training provision; water quality degradation
            should be prevented through the control of agrochemical
            uses, monitoring, and adequate maintenance planning.
